refnamediv.refpurpose: Definition file for a Software Authority router

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: drouter.map5 files define routers to be made available by the drouterd8 service via Software Authority protocol, one file per router to be defined. Map files must end with a .map extension and be placed in the /etc/drouter.d/maps/ subdirectory on the system running drouterd8.

refsect1.title: File Format
refsect1.para: The file format consists of sections, each of which contain configuration information in the form of keyword/value pairs. Each section begins with the name of the section in [] brackets, followed by zero or more keyword/value pairs, with the keyword and value seperated by an '=' sign. Lines starting with ; (semi-colon) are ignored, as are blank lines.

refsect2.title: The [Global] Section
refsect2.para: The [Global] section contains the following parameters:

listitem.para: Where name is the alphanumeric string that will appear in the output of the RouterNames command for this router.

Where num is the router number that will be advertised for this router in the output of the RouterNames command. Each Software Authority router must have a number (positive integer) that is unique across the entire drouterd8 service.
Where type is either audio or gpio.

refsect2.title: The [Inputnum] Section
refsect2.para: Each input in the router is defined by means of an [Inputnum] section, with num corresponding to the Input Number. Input numbers must start with 1 and be consecutive to the highest number.
Each [Inputnum] section must contain exactly one of each of the following two parameters:

listitem.para: Where ipv4-addr is the IPv4 address of the node hosting the input (an audio Source or Gpi, depending on the type of router), in dotted-quad notation. To leave an input position "undefined", specify an address of 0.0.0.0.
Where slot-num is the offset position of the input on the host node, starting with 1 and counting upwards, as returned by the LWRP SRC or GPI commands.

refsect2.para: Additionally, the following optional parameter may be included:

listitem.para: If present, the string str will be used as the name of the source in the output of the SourceNames command, in place of that derived from the source's LWRP definition.

refsect2.title: The [Outputnum] Section
refsect2.para: Each output in the router is defined by means of an [Outputnum] section, with num corresponding to the Output Number. Output numbers must start with 1 and be consecutive to the highest number.
Each [Outputnum] section must contain exactly one of each of the following parameters:

listitem.para: Where ipv4-addr is the IPv4 address of the node hosting the output (an audio Destination or Gpo, depending upon the type of router), in dotted-quad notation. To leave an output position "undefined", specify an address of 0.0.0.0.
Where slot-num is the offset position of the output on the host node, starting with 1 and counting upwards, as returned by the LWRP DST or GPO commands.

refsect2.para: Additionally, the following optional parameter may be included:

listitem.para: If present, the string str will be used as the name of the destination in the output of the DestNames command, in place of that derived from the destination's LWRP definition.

refsect2.title: The [Snapshotnum] Section
refsect2.para: Snapshots can be defined for the router by a [Snapshotnum] section for each desired snapshot, where num is the snapshot number that will be returned by the Snapshots command. Snapshot numbers must begin with 1 and be consecutive to the highest number.
Each [Snapshotnum] may contain the following parameters:

listitem.para: Where snap-name is the alphanumeric string that will be returned by the Snapshots command. Each [Snapshotnum] section must contain exactly one Name= parameter.

Where n is an integer, beginning with 1 and consecutively increasing for each route defined in the snapshot. The RoutenOutput parameter takes the output number of the route to be changed, as listed in the [Output] sections defined elsewhere in the same file. Each RoutenOutput section must have a corresponding RoutenInput section.

Where n is an integer, beginning with 1 and consecutively increasing for each route defined in the snapshot. The RoutenInput parameter takes the input number of the route to be changed, as listed in the [Input] sections defined elsewhere in the same file. Additionally, RoutenInput parameters may take a value of 0, which will result in the snapshot muting the referenced output. Each RoutenInput section must have a corresponding RoutenOutput section.
